awd_titl_txt: SHF: Small: Collaborative Research: Energy Efficient Strain Assisted Spin Transfer Torque Memory
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-volatile random access memory (NV-RAM) is often built with a device called spin transfer torque random access memory (STT-RAM), the main constituent of which is a circular nano-magnet. A bit is "written" into the nano-magnet by passing a spin-polarized current whose polarity determines whether bit "1" or bit "0" is written. The energy barrier between these states prevents the magnetization from switching spontaneously due to thermal noise, making the device non-volatile. Unfortunately, the energy dissipated in the writing current is 100-1000 times more than the energy dissipated in today's CMOS devices, which is a large cost to pay for non-volatility. This project seeks to demonstrate that temporarily reducing the energy barrier between the "up" and "down" magnetization states with surface acoustic waves (SAW) can significantly lower the current needed to write a bit and reduce the energy dissipation by orders of magnitude. This would make the SAW-assisted STT-RAM ideal for embedded processors, internet of things, large data centers and cyber-physical systems requiring low energy memory. At least 3 PhD students would be trained on the techniques of complementary nano-fabrication, nano-characterization and computer modeling. The investigators will hold a nano-magnetism workshop for high school students and will host under-represented K-12 students in their labs for a summer month, as well as leverage the "Nano-Days" program to reach out to high school students. 

The key technical approach in this research project will involve the following complementary experimental and modeling research directions: (i) Modeling the combined effect of strain and spin transfer torque (STT) on the magnetization switching in the presence of thermal noise (ii) Experimental demonstration of strain induced reduction in STT write current in optimized devices (guided by the modeling effort) (iii) Proof-of-concept demonstration of acoustic wave induced reduction in STT write current. The knowledge generated by this research would lead to better understanding of the combined effect of strain and spin torque on switching nano-magnetic memory elements and the switching probability in the presence of thermal noise. If successful, it would demonstrate a low energy paradigm for writing information in non-volatile nano-magnetic memory devices.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Magnetoresistive random-access memory (MRAM) is a promising candidate for beyond-CMOS memory and logic technologies due to its non-volatility, high retention and endurance, and robustness in high radiation environments. The elementary storage unit for MRAM is the magnetic tunnel junction (MTJ), which consists of two ferromagnetic layers (referred to as fixed and free layers) separated by a thin MgO layer that acts as a tunneling barrier. The binary state of the MTJ is determined by the relative magnetization orientation of the fixed and free layers. When the magnetization between the two layers has the same orientation, the MTJ is in the parallel (P) state, which is considered to be the low resistance state and when the magnetization of the fixed and free layers have opposite orientation, the MTJ is in the anti-parallel (AP) state, which is considered to be the high resistance state. Some of the common methods for switching the state of the MTJ is via an external field or current. In each case, there exists a trade-off between thermal stability (retention time) and switching energy; an MTJ with higher thermal stability dissipates more energy to switch.  Currently, switching (write) energies below 100 fJ can be achieved in MTJs with a thermal stability factor of 60, which corresponds to a retention time of 10 years, for STT switching; which is ~1000 times more than the energy required to switch a CMOS device. One promising solution for reducing the switching energy while maintaining high thermal stability is by temporarily modulating the anisotropy energy of the free layer via voltage-controlled methods. In particular, straintronic switching has the potential to reduce the switching energy down to ~1 aJ per bit at room temperature. In this method, an MTJ is fabricated on a piezoelectric substrate with the (magnetostrictive) free layer in contact with the substrate. Then a dc voltage is applied across the piezoelectric substrate, which generates a strain in the free layer and rotates its magnetization via the Villari effect to alter the MTJ resistance. This allows for the voltage-induced strain to act as an assisting mechanism for ultralow power switching. The dc voltage required to generate a given strain scales linearly with the piezoelectric layer thickness. For most piezoelectrics, sub-micrometer thicknesses will be required to reduce the switching voltage to below 100 mV. One way to overcome this problem of the voltage scaling with layer thickness is to employ a time-varying strain via a surface acoustic wave (SAW) launched in the piezoelectric layer. The SAW is confined to the surface of the piezoelectric, regardless of the layer thickness, and the time varying voltage required to generate the SAW has no dependence on the piezoelectric layer thickness.

In the first part of this project, we showed that when a SAW signal is applied to micron scale MTJs, the tunneling magnetoresistance (TMR) ratio and the AP and P state resistances all decrease at a specific SAW frequency determined by the device parameters. However, changes in the coercivities of the soft layers of the MTJs were found to be negligible, indicating that the effective magnetic field generated in the magnetostrictive soft layer by the SAW is miniscule compared to the coercive field.

In the second part of this study, we successfully fabricated nanoscaled MTJs on piezoelectric LiNbO3 substrates and generated the SAW signal using interdigitated transducers (IDTs). To the best of our knowledge, there are currently no studies examining the influence of the SAW signal on nano-scale MTJs. We analyzed the effect of the SAW signal on both nanometer and micrometer size MTJs and found their behaviors to be very different. Most surprisingly, the SAW signal caused the TMR ratio to drop below zero for the micrometer size MTJ, meaning that the AP-state resistance was temporarily less than the P-state resistance under SAW excitation. Our results provide insight into the dynamic behavior of MTJs under periodic strain and the dependence of this behavior on the device dimensions, as they are scaled down to nanometer sizes.

This work has been presented as an Invited Talk at the 68th annual conference on magnetism and magnetic materials in Nov 2023, which is the most prestigious conference for magnetic research community. The paper is accepted for publication as an invited paper. One of key researchers for this project, former PhD student and postdoc Dr. Brandon Zink, was recruited as a research associate by National Institute of Standard Technology (NIST) in Nov 2023.
